sentence: This podcast is brought to you by GIA, the Gemological Institute of America, protecting consumers and supporting the global gem and jewelry trade since 1931 through research, education and laboratory services.
Hello and welcome to the Rappaport Diamond podcast.
I'm Joshua Friedman, Senior Analyst at Rappaport, and my guest on this podcast was William Lam, CEO of mining company Lucara Diamond Corp.
The timing of this podcast couldn't be better.
We recorded it about a week after Lucara recovered the 2,492 carat rough diamond, the second largest in history at its Karowe mine in Botswana.
William hadn't even seen the stone in person when we spoke, but he was able to share  the story of how it was found and what the options might be for selling it.
He also put it in the context of the large stone market and reflected on the last time Lucara had a world famous diamond to sell.
While we were talking, William showed a few resin models of rough diamonds.
If you want to see the videos, you can find them in our social media channels.
Enjoy this unique episode.
in the morning where you are.
I'm very grateful for that.
When we scheduled this podcast initially, the recent discovery of the 2492 carat diamond hadn't happened yet.
So this is actually wonderful timing.
So I'm really, really excited about this.
Normally I would start by asking a little bit about you and the company, but I think that's been trumped by what happened last week.
So maybe if you could begin by telling us a little bit about the story of what happened when that huge diamond was found in Botswana.
Thanks, Joshua.
And thank you very much for having me on your podcast.
I must be the only CEO alive who's actually gotten two calls.
very similar to the one that happened.
And actually the stone was recovered on Monday, but it takes time to get Rowan to clean it before we can actually photograph it and put it into a press release.
But I now have two dates in my head.
One is the 15th of November, 2015, when the La Sede de la Rona was recovered.
And now the 19th of August, when this new stone was recovered.
And it's the exuberance of the person that I get the call from.
Because generally when you get a call early in the morning, it's not a good call.
Something has happened.
And that they are on complete polar opposite ends of the scale.
It's something which you don't want to know about.
And then when it's a stone like this, you do.
So Naseem Lahari, our managing director in country, she'll always send a WhatsApp message.
Good morning, William.
And that's just to check you from there.
And then I'll say morning, can I call?
Okay.
Yes, sure.
We can chat.
And then when you actually had her voice on the phone, you knew that it was not something bad, but it's a fantastic call to have, especially twice in one's career.
Once for the 1,109 karat Lasedi and now for the  to be named 2492 carats stone.
Right.
What do we know about how it was found?
I mean, who found it?
Where did they find it?
So it was found by technology.
And the one thing that I think Lucara can pride itself on is learning from the lessons of the past.
And when we recovered the Lacerdi, we know that there was a 374 carat piece that sticks directly onto it.
It's not a maybe fit.
It's an exact fit.
So the Lacerdi was in all likelihood over 2000 carats.
As soon as we'd actually recovered that one, we started a project to install XRT technology upfront in the process plant.

If you ever came to our plant and you stood on the stockpile feed conveyor and you see the material dropping off, and if you imagine having a stone the size of the lacedi, that might actually survive the fall.
Now, when we process EMPKS, we always keep the stockpile really high, but it's the 300-millimeter rock that falls onto the lacedi that could have cleaved this piece off.
was to recover the stones before there is any opportunity to damage them.
So in 2017, we installed two new XRT machines up front, right?
Right, right.
Just after the primary crush.
And these treat material up to about a 5,000 carat stone can be recovered from these machines.
We call them our mega diamond recovery.
So we are looking for the biggest of the big.
And this recent recovery came from the XRT systems, which we proactively taken the decision that if there was going to be anything we want to do recovered upfront.
The actual process of finding it was someone standing at a conveyor belt and just suddenly noticed there was a massive diamond going past?
that box during that day because we have two of these machines.
And I think it's more of the fact that it was recovered intact by the technology which we employed in 2017 versus singling out a person who touched it first.
Right.
So, William, I noticed that in the press release about this discovery of this stone, there was no clear mention of the quality of the diamond, which obviously had me asking a few questions myself.
But what can you tell me about the quality?
So it's still being assessed.
And as I mentioned, the stone was recovered last week, Monday.
We have an obligation to notify the  Ministry of Mines, especially we'd rather have them find out from us than from the military police to do the escorts for us to Gaborone.
So as soon as we'd notified the minister, it took about two minutes to get a call back from the office of the president saying he wants to see the stone and it's now still sitting on site.
So Tuesday morning, the stone was exported down.
We only got the stone into HF overnight because it takes 24 hour clean and that was just the original stone had a lot of crud and kimbleite still attached to it.
So we'd only done a preliminary clean before it actually went to the office of the president.
spent time over the weekend and again yesterday I got hold of the people down in Gaborone and asked one or two questions around and they said no it's back into cleaning.
So what we found with the Lacedia as well there was this red oxidized material that had gotten into one or two of the cracks and that takes quite a number of cleaning rounds to clean it out.

So we do see a lot of that stuff in there but at this point for me to be able to make a comment on the quality or the color of the stone I'm only going to see it next week so I'll have a better idea then.
And what's HF?
acid.
Oh, I see.
Fine.
And the obvious next question that people have on a CS stone like this is how it's going to be sold.
And we know you have an arrangement with HB.
Does that cover a stone like this?
No, this would be what we would consider a legacy stone.
The 1080 carat stone, which was recovered in September last year, was also classified as a legacy stone.
But that one went through to HB.
I think because of the notoriety of the stone and because of its significance to Botswana, we need to look at the best route to market for the stone.
And you never know.
doesn't necessarily mean that a stone of this size should be cut.
There's a lot of people that still don't understand why we went to Sotheby's with the Luseti back in 2016.
And at that point, Lucara had recovered a significant number of large stones.
And there were people that sat with 100 carat polished in their vault that they hadn't been able to move for two or three years.
So by us going to Sotheby's, we were looking for an alternative market to protect the value of the inventory, the polished inventory that some of our clients actually held.
So taking a stone like this,  and putting it into a collection in an unpolished form, it holds untold potential.
You cannot unpolish it.
So we were looking for collectors who would want to hold onto it.
Maybe when they had a reason to polish it, they wanted to split amongst their three children, they would then polish the stone.
But sadly, the diamond industry didn't quite see it that way.
And they thought that it would be better having the stone polished.
But I think we're going to learn from our mistakes when we look at how the stone is going to be sold, who is going to be sold to and the mechanism by which we message.

stone is not just a legacy stone for Botswana, an important stone for Lucara, but because of the stature that the stone actually represents and the excitement which I think the world has seen from the stone, this is a great good news story to bring a focus back to natural diamonds.
Let's bring more people in so that they can actually understand what a natural diamond represents, what it means for Botswana, how this stone actually was brought into the light.
A lot of people don't understand  that a rough diamond has a tumultuous task of getting to surface.
It travels between 200 and 500 kilometers in a magma tube at a thousand degrees Celsius to get to surface.
It is a phenomenon that we can actually even recover these stones without them being destroyed.
And that story of diamonds, I think, is what we need to celebrate.
Right.
One of the questions I was planning to ask you was whether we could see this ending up in a museum.
I was just thinking about today and I was wondering just how that works.
Would the customer be a donor to a museum?
who's come and buy it on behalf of the museum from you?
significant financial backing that museums have to acquire pieces such as this.
it's a legacy stone or not.
It's generally Lucara making that recommendation to the office, the ministry.
And you think he then basically approved that decision, right?
Yeah, there's a long way to go to understand what the ultimate solution for the stone is going to be.
We'll engage the government, we'll engage HB, we'll engage others to see what the market generally feels as well.
I think a lot of people think that because we have an agreement with HB that they are the only people that we speak to, and that's not true.
Right.
So on the topic of the potential price of  the stone.
Obviously there are so many variables and what's happened in the market in the last few years and the quality of the stone.
But if you just extrapolate from the cost of recent stones, you take the constellation from a few years ago, which sold for I think $77,000 per carat.
If you extrapolate to this, then you're talking $180-190 million.
And then even if you assume that the quality is lower and the market has weakened since then, there's still a good chance that this could be $100 million diamond, right?
quality and the color.
The constellation was a beautiful clean stone.
I wish it was the real one.
So this is the constellation diamond and it looked like this.
This is a resin model, but it was clean like this.
There was a small inclusion down the one side.
That one was what sold for $77,000 a carat and it's blocky.
It's just a fantastic yield stone, but it was white.
You could see, you could read through the stone.
This one does seem to have more of color to it, but again,  If you can find the right buyer who is looking for something which is the largest stone in living memory.
When we pulled out the Lacedi, we would say there was not a person alive who had seen a stone of this size.
And this one is just that next step up.
So there are avenues that we need to explore to find where we can maximize value for the stone for Botswana and for Lucara.
But do you think it could be a hundred million dollar diamond?
That's very difficult to say not having seen it and again explored the potential acquirers for the stone.
$100 million, I think we'd be very happy with $100 million.
But it is, a lot of people will ask me, well, where'd you find a buyer like that?
And it's going to be that buyer that wants to own something that there's a good chance nobody alive will ever get to see again.
When you look at the history that's been, what, 118 years since the Column.
Sure, our mind does produce a fairly large number of large stones, but this is truly a spectacular find.
in his hands.
What else do you know about what he said about the diamond?
the size and the weight.
And it's the way we did the Lacedi as well.
Anytime somebody came in, we'd make them close their eyes and hold their hands above the table.
And then you drop the stone into their hands.
And the first thing that you feel is the weight of the stone, because you're not expecting it.
And then it's a cool, it's always a cool surface.
And this one at 500 grams, I think most probably caught him by surprise as well.
But for him, this was a fantastic opportunity to showcase what Botswana actually has to offer.
And I think his best comment in the time that  was when our managing director asked him if he could see his hand through the stone.
And he picked up the stone and he said, I see roads, I see schools.
And that is exactly what diamonds mean to Botswana.
And if you ever sort of catch me on a bad day and you say that, oh, I'm thinking about buying a synthetic.
The most important thing for listeners to understand is what diamonds mean to Botswana.
And you go back to 1966 and you look at the state of Botswana at independence, second poorest country in the world.
in Africa.
And you look at where it is now, and it's not because they've had success exporting coal or gold or some other commodity, it's purely diamonds.
They have a growing copper sector at the moment.

But diamonds have transformed Botswana from the second poorest country to, I think it now has a top five GDP in Africa, which is significant considering the size of the economies for South Africa, Nigeria, and some others.
And it's truly shaped the way Botswana has actually developed.
And it's down to education, it's healthcare, it's all of these other things.
And that is  purely based on the natural diamond industry, which Botswana has excelled at ensuring that value goes back to its citizens.
And I think that's what people need to understand.
When you're buying a natural diamond, you're actually buying something which has made a huge difference in a person's life.
How much of an impact does a one-off diamond like this, a huge diamond like this have on Botswana, as opposed to just the kind of the regular volume of diamonds?
I think this is the notoriety.
And it's bringing people to Botswana.
you ever fly into Botswana, they have a diamond display and there's a booth where you can go and buy a Forevermark to be as diamond.
So they are trying to, excuse the pun, trying to marry people coming in on safari to what actually drives the economy of Botswana.

A single stone in terms of finances isn't going to make that much difference, not unless you sold it for a billion dollars, but it's the importance of bringing attention to, I want to own a Botswana diamond.
That's, I think, where the real reverence is going to come from, because if people can understand  what diamonds do for the people of Botswana.
It's not just about the romance, which that eternity that a diamond represents.
It's a diamond for good.
And I think Botswana is a brilliant example of that.
about the large stone mark and particularly this huge end.

How does pricing work for these huge stones and is there any sense that there's a price ceiling where a diamond can just get so big that the price per carat no longer increases with size like it does with smaller sizes?
I think there's always going to be a component of competition.
Somebody always wants to have the biggest, the most expensive, the shiniest.
I think when you get to graph polished out of the Lisseti, actually from the constellation as well, they were both plus 300 carat polished.
Those are fairly difficult to move because  the volume of people that have the financial resources to spend whatever, a hundred million dollars on a diamond is going to be fairly limited.
But I think when you start to look at what we would love to do with the stone, let's assume that it gets polished.
You want to use it to showcase.
And I'm going to give kudos to Lawrence Graf here to what he did with the Lesotho promise.
The necklace that he created, there's one large stone, but otherwise it is a necklace all from the single stone.
And that's where you start to celebrate.
Chopard did a really  good job.
They worked with Tache on the Queen of the Kalahari collection.
There was a 342 carat stone that they acquired from us and they created a full collection around that.
And I think instead of going for the largest, I think we're beyond the years now of a royal family wanting something in their crown jewels.
I think you have to create something which has a link back to Botswana, whether if it was in Namibia, you could create the desert rose type collection.

But there's something that you have to do to create a collection from the stone where  Everything comes from the single stone, which has its own significance, but there is value to be gained from not polishing the biggest one, but making something which is more appealing.
And that then lowers the size of the polish, but it doesn't necessarily minimize the value of what you've actually created.
Do we know where the Seddy Lerona polished is now?
I mean, is it around the consumer's neck already or what do we know?
I know that it was sold and then Lawrence Graf has the stones come back to him.
So it was gone.
I think it's back with Graf at the moment.
the large modified cushion that they polished out of it, from what I understand.
not just the exceptional stones, but those kind of 5-carat, 10-carat plus.
It seems, from the dealers I speak to, it's quite a patchy market at the moment.
It's maybe not struggling as much as some of the more bread and butter sizes, but it's not the easiest market to be in at the moment.
What do you hear from your customers and from the market about how that segment is?
So that's actually a really interesting question because with our agreement with HB, we now have a much more detailed understanding of what our stones actually polished to be.
And when we were selling  the stones on tender, you're literally getting a rough price.
And if you've got single stones, it will range anywhere from 10 to I think our highest was $65,000 a carat for a rough stone.
But you have no idea whether whoever acquired it made money from it.
With the HB agreement, we now have a window into the quality of the diamonds which come from our rough.
And about 65% of our total revenue is generated from five carat polished and above.
And out of those five carats, more than 50 to  60% end up as deflawless.
So I mentioned things like that because it talks to number one, the quality of the diamonds which we're recovering.
But that also then gives us a window into what that market is like.
And rough market seems to be way more volatile than the polished, the polished at the slow decline.
So what we're seeing with our revenues is a slightly less volatile reaction with the market because of the HPE agreement.
So we are seeing obviously a slow decline as people don't buy.
But what we are seeing from the sales is HPE have continued  to be able to move the plus five characters that they sell.
Oddly enough, the tops and nails that they get, these smaller stones, they move fairly quickly as well.
But HB does have a work with Odette's history.
He's got a fairly large Rolodex of people that are willing to continue to buy in the larger, higher qualities.
And I think that's it.
I think if you've got a D.I.F.
stone, it's a lot easier for people to acquire that than the lower qualities, especially in the larger sizes.
How have lab-grown diamonds affected this segment?
Very little.

And I think that's, again, I came on to talk about diamonds  is not necessarily Lucara, but it's one of the differentiating factors for Lucara as a company because our size distribution that we recover is so heavily weighted to the larger stones and the underground is just going to be that next level up.
The impact that we are seeing from Synthetix on the lower end has had very little impact on our margins.
I think when we look at Synthetix, anybody who's going out to buy a five-carat Synthetix to me may as well just give me the money.
I'll waste it for you because you look at the price reduction of Synthetix  over the last even three or four years, down by 90%.

So if you're going out to spend money, spend it on a smaller size, and I think Synthetix will find their place in the market, whether it ends up in custom jewelry, whether it ends up in a larger lower value engagement ring, that's going to be for the consumer to decide.
But I think we will see this bifurcation between the natural and the lab-grown stones somewhere in the next, my guess is, 18 months to two years, but they will have a home.
I think the amount of investment that has gone into setting up  up of lab-grown factories is you cannot negate that in the future of lab-grown stone.
But the impact on the plus five carat stones has been minimal, if not non-existent.

You can imagine how in theory there could be an impact because if the cache of having a 10 carat natural diamond, for example, might be damaged by the fact that someone else next to you could also have a 10 carat lab-grown diamond, the access to these things, availability to these things has grown because of lab-grown.
Yes.
If I'm sitting next to somebody, there's a certain level of honesty  that has to come as well.

And we've heard the stories of some guy proposing to his fiance or his girlfriend to be his fiance and he gives her a diamond, but he doesn't tell her that it's a lab grow and she finds out pretty close to the wedding.
And literally every single story that I've heard, the wedding always gets canceled because there's that deceptive nature.
And I think if you're going to sit there and say that this is a natural 10 carat stone and you're going to lie about it, well, that says something about your character.
And I wouldn't be sitting next to that person anyway.
Right.
In the large stones, or not necessarily  large, but large and high quality.
There has been a lot of suggestion in the last couple of years that during an economic downturn, the wealthy people are less affected by a downturn than mid range.
Do you agree with that?
And how has that impacted demand for deflauruses and high quality stones?
I think it comes back and it goes hand in glove with the answer from the previous question.
If you look at even what happened during COVID, the 10 most wealthy people on the planet had almost exponential increase in wealth.
So when the world is hurting,  you've actually got the rich get richer.
They're the ones that actually have the capacity to buy when others are selling.
And when we look at the market for these truly large exceptional stones, and I had to smile when you say large stones, because for us, our large stones are quite a bit larger than most others.
So when we talk about large stones, it is, do we have polished 50 and 100 carat stones?
Yes.
But I will say that when it comes to founding buyers who actually want to hold on to a hundred carat stone,  It doesn't generally fit into a piece of jewelry very well.
So that's where it goes back to the polishing of the largest owner polishing a collection, something that is actually usable.

And I think there's the balance between finding or creating something that somebody who actually has increasing wealth and is going to continue to buy is willing to buy versus something which is just going to sit in the vault or on display.
But to answer your question, yes, I think there is always going to be a market even in downturn period.
for the higher value stones because the people that are buying those are not being affected as much as those that would buy the smaller lower quality goods.
Right.
Moving back to Lucara and access to those large stones, how will the transition to underground mining at Karowei, how will that affect your access to these exceptional stones?
So this is the most interesting thing for me.
So a lot of people go, oh, you're spending $700 million going underground or 683 is the capital as it stands now.
That's an awfully large amount of money when you consider how much we spend  to build the original mine.
The original Capix was 120.
But when we look at our production profile, so over the last three or four years, we've only mined about 25% of what we call EMPKS.
It stands for East Magmatic Pyroclastic Kimberlite South.
There's no test, so we don't have to remember that one.

We just call it E. And all of the large stones that we've recovered to date, the Constellation, the Lacedi, the Averstar, all of them have come from the EMPKS, the Suello,  and this new recovery, all of them while processing EMPKS.
So you can imagine you've got this root zone, this extinct volcano, which we are mining.
And the last intrusion which we believe came up was this E material.

So the vast majority of what we see at depth is going to be E. So when the underground does mature, which is scheduled for the first half of 2028, up to 90% of the material that we process is going to be from this E phase of the kimberlust.
We've only been processing 25% to date and we've had these fabulous recoveries.
It's going to be a very interesting year, 2028, when we do start to see the vast majority of material that goes through the mill coming from the EMPKS.

And we're already looking at things like blast patterns and fragmentation to ensure that we are not going to be damaging the diamonds during the mining process so that they can actually get to the process plant in their unaltered state.
Right.
I don't want to turn what's obviously a positive into something pessimistic, but is there a risk  that there's just going to be too many of these stones and they'll lose value.
And that is something that if there's anything that keeps me awake at night, it's most probably that.
I think when we look at the project development and yes, there were the cost blowout and the schedule blowout that happened mid last year.
Those are things that we worry about.
But I think there's a fiduciary duty and a responsibility for Lucora not to throw everything out into the market.
It's something that way back Clifford Elphick from JEM and I discussed, obviously with the stones that come out of Leth Sang versus what we were producing.
I think there is that impact  that you have on the market.
I would love to find somebody come to me and say, hey, we've got a scientific requirement for diamonds.
We're going to be using diamond chips in our computers or something.
But that's actually a job for the synthetics, diamond chips to replace the silica.
But it is, I think it is one of the things where it's possibly the best problem in the world to have when you've over recovered, but you don't have to sell.
And I think when we look at the operating costs expected for the undergarno, a lot of the $680 million we're spending  now is on actual operating costs so we don't have to spend it while mining.
Literally, you're doing all of your blasting in this method that we're going to be using.
Our operating costs are going to be very similar to what we see now.
It's not that we now need to mine and sell more to overcome our costs, but even if we carried on selling at the rate at which we're selling now, we'll still generate a 65 plus percent EBITDA margin.
Not having to sell the diamonds to protect the  market is definitely something that we have in the back of our minds.

Just taking that to a sort of logical conclusion, and maybe I misunderstood you, you're saying that there's a plan to increase your long term stockpiles of large stones in order to protect market prices?
If that's what it comes to, we'll most certainly have to consider that, yes.
And is that something that you mentioned gem diamonds before?
Is that something that large stone miners have been planning to do together?
No, it was a conversation that we had around protecting the value and not flooding the market with them.
I think the way it was beneficial for Lucara in the  past because it was all about share price.
I think now there's a much greater emphasis of how we actually sell those things to protect the value.
But in the past, I think market was actually able to absorb what has been produced.
I think if we look at what the potential is for and look, the EMPK is made not to do the same as what it's doing on surface.
It is another 500 meters lower.
But if it does have the same potential down, then those are decisions which we'll have to make.
But we're not sitting around the rooms and you sell this one, you sell this one.
I think it comes down to company economics.
I think everybody has  to sell to keep the lights on.

and sizes anywhere up to, if we're selling up to 10 carats on Clara, so it's one to 10 on Clara in certain colors and qualities, but we get a lot more data in terms of what the price book for the rough should look like based on what the polished is selling for on Clara.
So it's this closed cycle loop.
And a lot of times there are other companies that have gone out and they've polished their own diamonds and sold them into the market, but those are also once off items.

When we look at the volume of diamonds going through Clara, we have a much higher statistical  understanding of what is driving the market in certain colors and we'll get a call from the office in Antwerp and they'll say don't send any of these qualities or these colors because they are not moving.
So we know that when those goods go into a tender that there's going to be weakness in those colors and clarity.
So it's a fantastic information gathering tool which allows us to better manage the internal expectations within the company specifically with regards to the smaller stones in the tenders.
Are you still holding out hopes that Clara will become a major revenue  stream or is shifting that more towards it being a source of market data, market information?
So one of the things that you would have seen if you had read our financials is it is marked as an asset for sale.
I think over the past five years, the level of competition within the diamond industry is pretty fierce.
I cannot understand and I guess I would be the same.
Other diamond miners do not want another miner to make money off the sales of their diamonds.

So having Clara as an asset internally within Lucara doesn't  Benefit the Clara platform because people just don't want us to make money or for the sale of their diamonds So having it as a standalone entity outside of Lucara We will continue to sell on the platform because we do see the benefits of it and it does Generate a higher margin than what we get on tender and we have tested that but leaving Clara within Lucara is not going to allow it to reach its full potential All right, I see but just so understand you still would be to retain a situation where Lucara would have access to that data.
It'd be to our data  Yes, right.
It would still be the current data.
Yes, when I say our data, it'll be our data from the stones that we sell on the platform.
I see.
And again, I'm having access to say Joe Blow's diamonds were being sold on the platform.
That doesn't necessarily inform what are we going to get in our tender because the qualities of their diamonds will be different.

OK, I wanted to ask before we finish a few questions about diamond provenance, because you touched on this before with jewelry pieces that are made entirely from one stone and from one rough stone, for example.

How has the fact that you have a clear and well-known  Providence for your stones benefited the company in the current environment of Russia sanctions and other conflict related concerns That's a very good question again because we've asked and we've said will somebody pay more if they know the provenance of a diamond and Sadly, the answer is no that way They actually look at it as they will pay less if it doesn't have the provenance So provenance is not driving incremental increases in value What it is is it's preventing you from getting a discount  discount on your diamonds.
And we asked, obviously in some discussions we've already had with certain people around this large stone and everybody's going, oh, well provenance.
And we sold stones and we've said to them, are people actually asking for the provenance?
And the answer is no.
I think if a person is going to buy, sure, they may want to know whether it's a Russian diamond, but that is a completely different sector.
But nobody's actually saying, is this a Botswana diamond?
And maybe that's something that we and the government and Devswana need to focus on is how do we want the market to  or how do we portray diamonds that people want to buy a Botswana diamond?
But at the moment, it's, is it a Russian diamond?
No, then it's fine.
But it's that other way of looking at it.
How do we get them to ask for a Botswana diamond?
And then it would be a premium.
Right.

Leaving out the specific Russia issue, does this mean that the average consumer is actually more interested in the discount than is more interested in getting a discount than in having peace of mind that the diamond is not funded something they don't want their diamond to have  It sounds like that's a loaded question, but let's put it this way.
There are going to be differences in generations.

I think the younger generation that is coming up now who might only be buying diamonds in five to 10 years time, they may be more willing to pay for what the diamond represents versus what we see now.
But the actual retailers are not the ones that are actually helping.
When you go past, the airports are fantastic.
You walk around and you go past any jeweler and they will always  have a discount on diamonds and that's not helping the industry at all.
They need to turn over the inventory so they are the ones that are always going to have the discounts.
So the consumer goes, oh, I can get a discount here, here and here.
That becomes part of how they actually shop for diamonds.
They're looking for the discounts.

They're not going out there looking for something which is special, attractive and has meaning because the way that they are fed information continuously every time they walk past a jeweler is the diamonds are on discount.
So I think that's part of how we  actually have to message to the market that this diamond is worth way more than the discount that you are actually saving.
Right.
And how do you think it would actually be possible to tell that story about Botswana and create a premium for Botswana diamonds?
Quite a few years ago, I was in Shanghai and we went into one of those fancy sort of old and 300 year old buildings, but that converted into a mall.
Then we went into a jewelry store there and we walked in and they had their general diamond display.
And then they had a fantastic just single wall  where it was all about South African diamonds.
And I think they were buying them either from Petra, but it was a guaranteed South African diamond.

We'll have to change that soon.
But it was a show of, this is where diamonds were really, the whole Kimberlite, which is where diamonds get their names, all of this came from South Africa.
So they had a South African display.
And I think if you  people start to market like Tiffany used to do with the Ellendale yellows.
If you can create a brand around those specific diamonds, and I think you can with Botswana, the Providence is so easy to do.
You know exactly where they're coming from.
Ours may be a little bit easier than what Deptswana does because there's some aggregation that happens there.
But you can actually start to segregate within your collection.
These are Botswana diamonds.
These are Canadian diamonds.
I can go down to the local mall here and there's a jeweler called Arctic Diamonds and they specialize in selling Canadian diamonds.
That's what we can most probably do, but it requires the retailers to see value in that versus putting the 40% discount on diamonds price out.
